case_name: Padmanabha Setty v. K. P. Papiah Setty

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 756 of 1965 was filed as an appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 756 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 9, 1965 of the Mysore High Court in Civil Revision Petition No. 1044 of 1962.

facts.text: Mysore High Court delivered judgment and order dated April 9, 1965 in Civil Revision Petition No. 1044 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 9, 1965 of the Mysore High Court in Civil Revision Petition No. 1044 of 1962. K. Venkatarangaiengar G. L. Sanghi, J. B. Dadachanji C. Mathur and Ravinder Narain, for the appellant.

facts.text: Padmanabha Setty is the tenant of non-residential premises No. 281, Old Tharagupet, Bangalore City.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant before us, Padmanabha Setty, hereinafter referred to as the tenant, was the tenant of a number- residential premises No. 281, Old Tharagupet, Bangalore City. be tenant had installed some machinery in the premises.

facts.text: The tenant installed some machinery in the premises.

anchor.surface_text: The tenant had installed some machinery in the premises. The respondent, K. P. Papiah Setty, is the landlord. He had purchased the premises for his own use and occupation, namely, for the purpose of shifting his business which hewas carrying on in a rented building to the premises in dispute.

facts.text: K. P. Papiah Setty is the landlord who purchased the premises for his own use and occupation to shift his business from a rented building.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, K. P. Papiah Setty, is the landlord. He had purchased the premises for his own use and occupation, namely, for the purpose of shifting his business which hewas carrying on in a rented building to the premises in dispute.

facts.text: Landlord filed application under s.8(3)(a)(ii) of the Act for eviction of the tenant on ground of requiring premises for own use and occupation.

anchor.surface_text: The landlord tiled an application under s.8 3  a  ii  of theAct for the eviction of the tenant on the ground that he required the premises in dispute for his own use and occupation.

facts.text: First Munsiff, Bangalore directed eviction of the tenant.

anchor.surface_text: The III Additional Judge had set aside the order of the First Munsiff, Bangalore, who had directed the eviction of the tenant from the premises in dispute.

facts.text: III Additional District Judge, Bangalore set aside the order of the First Munsiff.

anchor.surface_text: whereby the High Court set aside the order passed by the III Additional District Judge, Bangalore. The III Additional Judge had set aside the order of the First Munsiff, Bangalore,

facts.text: First Munsiff and III Additional District Judge found that the landlord required the premises for his bona fide use and occupation for shifting his business.

anchor.surface_text: It is number necessary to give the other allegations made in the application as both the First Munsiff, Bangalore, and the III Additional District Judge, Bangalore, have found that the landlord required the premises for his bonafide use and occupation, namely, for shifting his business from the rented premises to the premises in dispute.

facts.text: III Additional District Judge held that under s.8(3)(a)(ii) landlord not entitled to possession unless prepared to vacate the shops in which he was trading.

anchor.surface_text: The III Additional District Judge, however, held that under s. 8 3  a  ii  the landlord was number entitled to possession of the premises in dispute unless and until he was prepared to vacate the shops in which he was trading at the time.

facts.text: This finding of III Additional District Judge was contrary to Mysore High Court decision in S. G. Narayanappa and Bros. v. A. N. Narasimhiah.

anchor.surface_text: This finding of the learned Additional Judge was companytrary to the decision of the Mysore High Court in S. G. Narayanappa and Bros. v. A. N. Narasimhiah 1 .

facts.text: Landlord filed revision petition under s.17 of the Act in Mysore High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The landlord then filed a revision petition under s. 17 of the Act, and the High Court, following the decision in S. G. Naravanappa and Bros. v. A. N. Narasimhiah 1  set aside the order of the Additional District Judge.

facts.text: Mysore High Court set aside the order of III Additional District Judge following S. G. Narayanappa decision.

anchor.surface_text: and the High Court, following the decision in S. G. Naravanappa and Bros. v. A. N. Narasimhiah 1  set aside the order of the Additional District Judge. The tenant having obtained special leave, the matter is number before us.

facts.text: Tenant obtained special leave to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The tenant having obtained special leave, the matter is number before us. Two points are raised before us  1  that the companystruction put upon s. 8 3  a   ii  of the Act by the Mysore High Court is erroneous

facts.text: Landlord was carrying on business in a rented building.

anchor.surface_text: He had purchased the premises for his own use and occupation, namely, for the purpose of shifting his business which hewas carrying on in a rented building to the premises in dispute.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Mysore High Court has jurisdiction under s.17 of the Act for revision.

facts.text: Tenant raised point that construction of s.8(3)(a)(ii) by Mysore HC erroneous, Madras HC correct.

anchor.surface_text: Two points are raised before us  1  that the companystruction put upon s. 8 3  a   ii  of the Act by the Mysore High Court is erroneous and the companystruction put upon a similar provision by the Madras High Court in V. Thanappa Chetty v. Arcot Govindaswami Naicker 2  is companyrect

facts.text: Mysore Act 30 of 1951 regulates letting of houses, controls rents, prevents unreasonable eviction.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was passed to regulate the letting of residential and number-residential houses and to companytrol the rents of such houses and to prevent unreasonable eviction of tenants therefrom in the State of Mysore.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Mysore HC correct in construction of s.8(3)(a)(ii), dissenting from Madras HC.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, with great respect to Subba Rao, J., Ahmed Ali Khan, J., arrived at the companyrect companyclusion. A tenant who can be evicted under the companyditions prescribed in s. 8 2  of the Act cannot be said, in our view, to be entitled to the possession of the premises of which he is a tenant.
in exercise of our jurisdiction under Art. 136 of the Constitution, say that the High Court should not have set aside the order of the Additional District Judge on this ground.

A tenant who can be evicted under the conditions prescribed in s. 8 2  of the Act cannot be said, in our view, to be entitled to the possession of the premises of which he is a tenant.

arguments.qualifiers: in our opinion, with great respect

arguments.claim: High Court correctly set aside Additional District Judge's order due to material irregularity in not following binding Mysore High Court precedent

anchor.surface_text: There is no force in the second point raised by the learned counsel of the tenant. It is true that the jurisdiction of a High Court under provisions similar to S. 17 of the Act is limited, but we cannot say that the High Court was wrong in holding that the Additional District Judge acted with material irregularity

holdings.text: The construction put upon s.8(3)(a)(ii) of the Act by the Mysore High Court is correct and the construction put upon a similar provision by the Madras High Court is incorrect.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, with great respect to Subba Rao, J., Ahmed Ali Khan, J., arrived at the correct conclusion. A tenant who can be evicted under the conditions prescribed in s. 8 2  of the Act cannot be said, in our view, to be entitled to the possession of the premises of which he is a tenant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tenant's statutory protection is immunity from eviction under s.8(2) conditions, not positive entitlement to possession; equates neither to ownership nor absolute right; purposive reading prevents unreasonable eviction while allowing shift from rented to owned premises; follows Mysore HC, dissents Madras HC.

holdings.text: A tenant who can be evicted under the conditions prescribed in s.8(2) of the Act cannot be said to be entitled to the possession of the premises.

anchor.surface_text: A tenant who can be evicted under the conditions prescribed in s. 8 2  of the Act cannot be said, in our view, to be entitled to the possession of the premises of which he is a tenant. No doubt he cannot be evicted till one or more of the conditions prescribed by the section are fulfilled,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory immunity from eviction is negative (restricts landlord), not positive right to possession; distinguished from Federal Court observations; s.8(2) conditions show possession not absolute.

holdings.text: In the context of s.8(3)(a)(ii), the words 'entitled to possession' have a more positive content akin to owner's right, not tenant's precarious possession under rent Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, in the context the words entitled to possession have a more positive content and are more akin to the right of possession which an owner has in respect of the building owned and occupied by him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislative intent to prevent unreasonable evictions does not bar landlord shifting from rented (evictable under s.8(2)) to owned premises; policy favors own occupation over tenancy.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in holding that the Additional District Judge erred in not following the decision of the Mysore High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In conclusion we are of the view that the High Court was right in holding that the Additional District Judge erred in not following the decision of the Mysore High Court in S. G. Narayanappa and Bros. v. A. N. Narasimhiah.

holdings.reasoning_summary: District Judge's contrary interpretation despite binding precedent constitutes error justifying High Court's intervention.

holdings.text: The High Court was not wrong in holding that the Additional District Judge acted with material irregularity in not following the Mysore High Court decision.

anchor.surface_text: There is no force in the second point raised by the learned counsel of the tenant. It is true that the jurisdiction of a High Court under provisions similar to S. 17 of the Act is limited, but we cannot say that the High Court was wrong in holding that the Additional District Judge acted with material irregularity

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.17 revision jurisdiction limited, but material irregularity (ignoring binding precedent from same court in related case) warrants interference; Supreme Court under Art.136 will not disturb.

holdings.text: Supreme Court cannot interfere under Art.136 to say High Court should not have set aside the Additional District Judge's order on the ground of material irregularity.

anchor.surface_text: but we cannot, in exercise of our jurisdiction under Art. 136 of the Constitution, say that the High Court should not have set aside the order of the Additional District Judge on this ground.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limited Art.136 jurisdiction; High Court correctly identified material irregularity.

In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.
